citation.article-title: Paracoccus thiocyanatus sp. nov., a new species of thiocyanate-utilizing facultative chemolithotroph, and transfer of Thiobacillus versutus to the genus Paracoccus as Paracoccus versutus comb. nov. with emendation of the genus.

p.s: Emended description of the genus Paracoccus
Paracoccus (pa.ra.coc'cus, Gr. prep. para, like, alongside of; Gr. n. coccus, a grain, berry; ML masc. n. Paracoccus, like a coccus)
Cells are spherical or rod-shaped, 0.5-1.3 μm wide and 0.9-2.0 μm long, occurring singly, in pairs, in chains or in clusters.
No resting stage is known.
Gram-negative.
Nonmotile (one species is motile, having a tuft of polar flagella).
Metabolism is respiratory with oxygen as the terminal electron acceptor.
Some species are also able to use nitrate as the acceptor.
Aerobic chemoorganotrophs or facultative chemolithotrophs.
Facultative chemolithotrophic species utilize reduced sulphur compounds or molecular hydrogen as energy source.
Mesophilic, neutrophilic and non-halophilic.
Catalase and oxidase positive.
A wide variety of organic compounds are used as carbon and energy sources.
Major quinone is Q-10.
Major nonhydroxyl fatty acids are [C18:1+C19cyc], which constitute 60-80% of total non-hydroxyl acids.
3-Hydroxyl fatty acids are present, with 3-OH C10:0 predominating.
Some species also contain 3-OH C14:0.
The G + C content of the DNA is 64-70 mol%.
Phylogenetic position is the α-3 subclass of the Proteobucteria.
Type species: Paracoccus denitrifians ([ Beijerinck 1910] Davis 1969, 384) Ludwig et al. 1993.
